items.title: Add Support to Remove Specific Transitive Dependencies
items.body:
It would be nice to have the ability to remove transitive dependencies from a binary target. My use case is that I have some `python_libary` targets that depend on TensorFlow. It would be possible with split up code in such a way to avoid this, but It would end up creating more targets and files than is necessary for the project. I have a set of `python_binary` targets that shouldn't have Tenserflow, so this is just increasing the size of the resulting pex file. 

This is probably possible to do by creating a new target or extending the `python_binary` one.  I've read through the docs on how to create a new target. I haven't figured out how to do it, although it seems possible. It would be really helpfull to have a documented way of doing this. 

One alternative is to extend a feature that is in pants already `!some_dep` in the dependencies is ignored. This doesn't currently apply to transitive dependencies. The extension could be `!!some_dep` is removed from transitive dependencies as well. The concern being that this might make the interface a little to magical. 

I think this could be a useful feature for other people's use cases since there are a lot of large dependencies out there that can cause bloat in output binaries.

items.title: SSL CA throwing error trying to connect: invalid certificate: UnknownIssuer
items.body:
Hi, I'm trying to use pants v2 on my work projects but we use proxy for everything and normally we point to the CA file using environment variables such as `REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE`.

I'm not familiar with Rust at all but seems like `rustls` doesn't support using envs so I was wondering if there is a workaround for this already implemented on Pants or if implementing something is even possible giving the current state of `rustls`.

items.title: "Filesystem changed during run: retrying " messages are terrifying
items.body:
See, e.g., https://gist.githubusercontent.com/benjyw/9575b60e20ef3893ae1b42726f08d7c5/raw/7047e78d0beefa9bf72f7be5d7a4c21b60d0373b/useless%2520log%2520message

The stringification of the rule can be a massive, multi-screen wall of text (420K to be precise, in that example). We have to pare it down to one useful line.

items.title: pantsd restarts on every operation in example repo
items.body: To reproduce, check out https://github.com/pantsbuild/example-python branch `2.0` and run, say, `./pants test helloworld/greet/greeting_test.py` twice in a row, even with no source changes whatsoever.

items.title: Auto-generate documentation for target types
items.body:
We should have all the information from `./pants target-types --details` show up on the website.

It's not clear how we should handle `PluginFields`, as those will only show up depending on which backends are activated. Possibly, we should indicate it's a plugin field? This might also be noisy - the error messages already will complain when an unrecognized field is used.

items.title: Implement target file intra-dependency toggle
items.body:
In #10455 we concluded that moving forward, targets would be metadata applied to files, rather than collections of files. And in order for file deps to be useful, the files within a target should not automatically depend on one another. But:
>  ... this is a practical implication that might impact users migrating to 2.0, and so we might want to consider either 1) tying whether intra-dependencies are automatically added to whether Python import inference is enabled, or 2) adding an independent toggle.

This issue covers either adding that toggle, or tying the addition of intra-target file dependencies to the imports inference flag.

items.title: setup-py should operate on explicit "python_distribution" targets
How to specify JUnit test resources (non-source code)
items.body:
Hi, the following BUILD file worked in 1.4.0, but not in 1.5.0, and I could not find any mention of it in the release notes or docs:

```
junit_tests(name='test',
  sources = rglobs('src/test/java/*.java'),
  dependencies = [
    '3rdparty:junit',
    ':lib',
  ],
  resources = [
    'src/test/resources'
  ],
 )
```

items.title: flaky test: BanditIntegrationTest.test_3rdparty_plugin is flaky depending on Python version
items.body:
`BanditIntegrationTest.test_3rdparty_plugin` is flaky because the `bandit-aws` PyPi package referenced in the test is flaky depending on the Python version. `bandit-aws` only checks `ast.Str` nodes for problems and not `ast.Constant nodes` which show up on more recent versions of Python when parsing the bad.py example. Thus, using `bandit-aws` in the test results in the test being flaky.

On Python 3.8.5:

```
Python 3.8.5 (default, Jul 21 2020, 10:48:26)
[Clang 11.0.3 (clang-1103.0.32.62)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ast
>>> m = ast.parse(b"aws_key = 'JalrXUtnFEMI/K7MDENG/bPxRfiCYzEXAMPLEKEY'\n")
>>> a = m.body[0]
>>> a.value
<_ast.Constant object at 0x102d59160>
>>> a.value.value
'JalrXUtnFEMI/K7MDENG/bPxRfiCYzEXAMPLEKEY'
```

Note that Python 3.8 generates a `ast.Constant` node.

On Python 3.6.8:

```
Python 3.6.8 (default, Jul 29 2020, 18:41:24)
[GCC 5.4.0 20160609] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ast
>>> m = ast.parse(b"aws_key = 'JalrXUtnFEMI/K7MDENG/bPxRfiCYzEXAMPLEKEY'\n")
>>> a = m.body[0]
>>> a.value
<_ast.Str object at 0x7f8202ee03c8>
>>> a.value.
a.value.col_offset  a.value.lineno      a.value.s
>>> a.value.s
'JalrXUtnFEMI/K7MDENG/bPxRfiCYzEXAMPLEKEY'
```

Note that Python 3.6 generates a `ast.Str` node for the same code!

`bandit-aws` only checks ast.Str nodes, not ast.Constant:

```
@test.checks('Str')
@test.test_id('C100')
def hardcoded_aws_key(context):
    node = context.node
    if AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID_REGEX.fullmatch(node.s):
        entropy = shannon_entropy(node.s, AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID_SYMBOLS)
        if entropy > AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID_MAX_ENTROPY:
            return bandit.Issue(
                severity=bandit.LOW,
                confidence=bandit.MEDIUM,
                text=("Possible hardcoded AWS access key ID: %r" % node.s))
    elif AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY_REGEX.fullmatch(node.s):
        entropy = shannon_entropy(node.s, AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY_SYMBOLS)
        if entropy > AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY_MAX_ENTROPY:
            return bandit.Issue(
                severity=bandit.MEDIUM,
                confidence=bandit.MEDIUM,
                text=("Possible hardcoded AWS secret access key: %r" % node.s))
```

Note the `@test.checks('Str')`!

Moreover, I could not find the source repository for `bandit-aws` and had to open the wheel to find the source.

items.title: `--dynamic-ui` results in the last log message not being outputted
items.body:
Correct behavior:

```
▶ ./pants test src/python/pants/core/goals/{fmt,test}_test.py --no-pantsd --no-dynamic-ui
10:44:18 [WARN] Completed: Run Pytest - tests succeeded: src/python/pants/core/goals/test_test.py
10:44:18 [WARN] Completed: Run Pytest - tests succeeded: src/python/pants/core/goals/fmt_test.py
```

Incorrect behavior:
```
▶ ./pants test src/python/pants/core/goals/{fmt,test}_test.py --no-pantsd
10:45:51.19 [INFO] Completed: Run Pytest for src/python/pants/core/goals/fmt_test.py
10:45:51.19 [WARN] Completed: Run Pytest - tests succeeded: src/python/pants/core/goals/fmt_test.py
```

When run again, the message doesn't show up at all, even though we're not using panstd:

```
▶ ./pants test src/python/pants/core/goals/{fmt,test}_test.py --no-pantsd

src/python/pants/core/goals/fmt_test.py                                         .....   SUCCESS
src/python/pants/core/goals/test_test.py                                        .....   SUCCESS
```

Apply this diff:

```diff
diff --git a/src/python/pants/core/goals/test.py b/src/python/pants/core/goals/test.py
index 057d6503c..1a5a82de0 100644
--- a/src/python/pants/core/goals/test.py
+++ b/src/python/pants/core/goals/test.py
@@ -88,7 +88,7 @@ class TestResult(EngineAware):
     def level(self):
         if self.status == Status.FAILURE:
             return LogLevel.ERROR
-        return None
+        return LogLevel.WARN
 
     def message(self):
         result = "succeeded" if self.status == Status.SUCCESS else "failed"
```

items.title: Fix `lint` reports when a linter returns multiple results
items.body:
It's possible for a linter to partition targets and return multiple individual `LintResult`, e.g. to partition based on Python interpreter constraints. If the user runs with `--per-target-caching`, they will also get multiple distinct `LintResults` for each linter.

When this happens, `--lint-reports-dir` no longer works safely. We will correctly generate a unique report for each individual `LintResult`, but they will all have an identical report name. Because we call `write_digest` in a for loop, we don't error in this case due to an inability to merge the reports; rather, we simply overwrite the previous file.

To fix this, we need a way to safely rename every file to not collide. Then, we should use `MergeDigests` to combine it all, and call `Workspace.write_digest()` in one single call. Possibly, the naming scheme should be `{linter_name}/{partition_number}`, e.g. `flake8/1.txt`, `flake8/2.txt`, and so on.

Alternatively, we could simply error in this case and say that `--lint-reports-dir` only works if a) you do not use `--per-target-caching` and b) the linter did not end up partitioning the targets.

--

Pants should not attempt to do any merging into one single file. If we wanted to do something like that, we should instead contribute that feature upstream to those linters.

items.title: Enable streaming output in relevant locations
items.body:
The `EngineAware` interface allows for conditionally rendering a message as a workunit completes. This was intended to allow for streaming output of failures from relevant processes.  `TestResult` already [uses it](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/685e51db38e3d977824dca2fdb945f0faab31730/src/python/pants/core/goals/test.py#L88-L95), but only to render the fact that it failed, rather than any process output.

In particular, we'll likely want to move the stdout/stderr rendering in `lint` and `test` to streaming output from `TestResult` (conditional on the setting added in #10484) and `LintResult`... (while continuing to render a summary at the end).

items.title: [v2] Noisy console message when file system changes
items.body: When the file system changes underneath pants, it detects it and retries running the goal. However, the error message that gets logged is super verbose and noisy. example: ![noisy-msg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1268088/88987129-d0950100-d289-11ea-8737-5ec509c93ba0.gif) @Eric-Arellano

items.title: [v2] running `binary` goal (for a python_binary) doesn't create usable caches for a subsequent `run` goal on the same target.

```
15:33:12.84 [DEBUG] Completed: pants.engine.internals.graph.resolve_target
15:33:12.84 [DEBUG] Completed: pants.engine.internals.graph.resolve_targets
```
and pants gets stuck at that point. 

This issue has the same symptoms of [#10291](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/10291), so updated from v1.30 to 2.0.0.dev2 and even to 2.0.0.dev6 and unfortunately seeing the same behaviour across the versions.

Stuck here and lost for ideas on how to proceed. Any help would be appreciated.

items.title: Text file busy when attempting to execute script written into sandbox
items.body:
Using a `Process` to invoke an `is_executable=True` script can result in:
```
Error launching process: Os { code: 26, kind: Other, message: "Text file busy" }
```

We have tests that cover this behavior: https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/49f5a0aa8b68a9f079481d7f6a682b217ad9742b/src/python/pants/engine/process_test.py#L250-L277 ... so it's possible that this is non-deterministic.

items.title: Enable python imports inference by default
items.body:
There is consensus that we should enable python imports inference by default. We should likely do this before `2.0.0.alpha0` to ensure that we get as much feedback as possible.

This relates to #10467, because with imports inference enabled by default, `__init__.py` and `conftest.py` inference can likely use the same mapping to discover underlying files.

items.title: Improve Protobuf's handling of `__init__.py` files
items.body:
Now that we no longer automagically create files, it's confusing what users should do with Protobuf. 

If they aren't using PEP 420, they will need to create an `__init__.py` in the `protobuf_library()` folder, along with a `python_library` target to own it. Then, the new `__init__.py` dependency inference rule will find this file and infer a dependency on it. This is not at all obvious, nor elegant to require putting a Python file in your generic `.proto` folder.

Instead, we should likely add an option `generate_init_pys` in a new `[protoc-python]` subsystem, along with a plugin field on `protobuf_library` called `generate_init_pys`. If true, this will generate the `__init__.py` file automatically.

items.title: Consider re-enabling string-based python import inference as optional
items.body: Python string-based import inference uses regexes to identify strings that probably represent classes/modules, and infer dependencies on them. This is overkill for a lot of folks, but can be useful in particular for Django, so we should consider putting it behind an option.

items.title: Cycles involving file addresses not always permitted
items.body:
A case like:
```
pants.engine.internals.graph.CycleException: Dependency graph contained a cycle:
-> src/python/example/migrations:migrations
   src/python/example/__init__.py
-> src/python/example/migrations:migrations
```
...can currently fail. And this can be triggered by #10441.

A workaround is to split the `__init__.py` file out into its own target, but this shouldn't be necessary.

items.title: __init__ and conftest inference will pull in non-Python owners of those files
items.body:
The `__init__.py` and `conftest.py` inference rules added in #10441 will pull in the owning targets of those files, regardless of their type. And currently, unlike `imports` inference, they also won't fail for ambiguity.

It's likely that unlike `imports`,  `__init__.py` and `conftest.py` should fail if there are 1) no, or 2) too many owners of the appropriate type.

items.title: Always use generated subtargets
items.body:
Currently, if there are multiple owners of a source file, then we do not use generated subtargets:

https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0a61cf8d34eeee9609c7ff0c5e5f71a623dc1dc8/src/python/pants/engine/internals/graph.py#L277-L284

We solely do this to avoid the representation problem of how to represent a file address when there are multiple of them, but they have different `generated_base_target_name`. In Pants output, like `./pants list`, we would show the same file `foo.txt` multiple times, which looks redudant, even though they're different targets. We'd need a syntax like `foo.txt@:original` to show the base target when there was ambiguity.

--

Why change this?
1. It makes the experience with file arguments more consistent for end users. We no longer have a special case. When using file args, you always get generated subtargets / files, no matter what.
2. We can remove `AddressWithOrigin` et al. The only reason we use `WithOrigin` right now is for `SpecifiedSourceFiles`. If we fix this issue, then there is no need for `SpecifiedSourceFiles` as described in https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/pull/10454. This results in much less complexity for plugin authors to no longer need to know about `OriginSpec`.

--

Note that we will continue to need to use the original owning address if we detect a deleted file:

https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0a61cf8d34eeee9609c7ff0c5e5f71a623dc1dc8/src/python/pants/engine/internals/graph.py#L259-L261

This is important for `--changed-since` to work properly.

items.title: Implement "file dependencies" via `AddressWithSource`
items.body: This is an improvement on generated subtargets. See https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/10423 for the motivation of changing.

items.title: Test that every backend can be loaded without rule graph issues
items.body:
We want automated tests to ensure that the rule graph is valid for each situation:

- Zero backends activated.
- Every backend activated, which should catch ambiguity.
- Each distinct backend activated, with no others activated, which should catch Too Few Params.
    - In the future, we want backends to be able to express dependencies on other backends. In the meantime, we should ensure that users do not experience unpleasant rule graph errors because they didn't have the correct dependency backend activated.

items.title: Loading `pants.backend.codegen.protobuf.python` fails in dev releases
items.body:
Somewhere between `2.0.0.dev2` and `2.0.0.dev4`, loading `pants.backend.codegen.protobuf.python` from pants wheels in a dev release (see https://github.com/pantsbuild/example-python/pull/26) began to fail.

Running from sources (with light edits to the `pants_from_sources` script) works fine, so it seems like something is potentially not packaged in the release wheel that should be.

items.title: Are generated subtargets a misfeature?
items.body:
## What are generated subtargets?
When possible, Pants will generate multiple smaller targets from one original target. Each generated target will have exactly one sources file.

For example, if a target owns 5 files, Pants would generate 5 new targets. All of the metadata gets copied from the original, except for the `address` and the `sources` field.

If a file has multiple owning targets, then we will never attempt to generate a subtarget because it is ambiguous where to copy the metadata from.

## When are they used?

1. File arguments: when safe, we will generate a subtarget for each file specified. Otherwise, we use the original.
2. `--changed-since`: this is essentially sugar for file arguments. Same semantics as file arguments.
3. Explicit file dependencies in BUILD files.
    * We error if there are multiple owners.
4. Dependency inference: when safe, we generate a subtarget for the specific file that's imported.

## Open questions

### Dependencies on files in the same owner

Imagine you have the target `:utils`. `strutil.py` depends on `dirutil.py`. In the BUILD file, `:utils` does not include a dependency on `dirutil.py` because that is already in the `sources` field; Dependency inference is also disabled. Then, `./pants dependencies strutil.py` will end up not including `dirutil.py` nor `:utils`, and we won’t include `dirutil.py` anywhere in the closure.

### No mechanism to disable generated subtargets
The only way to get the feature to not work is that you have multiple owning targets.

We could possibly add a global flag.

## Pros

1. If you were not already using one target per file, then you will get finer-grained caching without any new BUILD file boilerplate.
   - Finer-grained caching means that we invalidate less frequently, i.e. that we get more cache hits.
   - Finer-grained caching also results in slightly smaller chroots, as we don't copy over as many files.
         - Is this actually noticeable?
2. File arguments (almost always) operate at the file level.
    - Previously, file arguments were really sugar to operate on targets. We only operated at the file level with `lint`, `fmt`, and `test` due to special logic.
    - Arguably, this makes file arguments more consistent and more useful, as something like `./pants dependencies foo.py` will only show the deps of that file (if dep inference is enabled).
3. Artificial cycles at the target level are less common.
    - This requires that you use dependency inference, however.
    - We agreed that we must tolerate cycles, at least upon request, so this is no longer a major win.
4. Starts decoupling describing metadata from the dependency graph.
     - There is a tension between wanting to describe metadata coarsely but also wanting fine-grained dependencies. This feature allows you to get both. 

## Cons

1. File addresses are deceptive.
   - We output a file name for generated subtargets, but it's not really a file. It's a target that owns exactly one file and was generated from some other target.
   - This nuance risks confusion; it hides key information about how Pants works, i.e. that Pants cares about the metatadata for that target, not only the source file.
2. We now must teach two concepts, rather than one. 
    - If you have any `files()`, `resources()`, or `python_requirement_library()` targets, you will always have conventional targets.
    - Because it's so common to use those target types, we will still need to teach conventional targets.
3. A user's experience varies substantially depending on if they use file arguments or address arguments, and dep inference or not.
     - This has a risk for confusion why something works one way, but not another.
     - The tool feels less unified and less consistent.
     - See https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/pull/10420#issue-454768171 for a concrete issue we had in Toolchain because of this. If we use file args, Pants works; otherwise, it errors.
4. No mechanism to determine the owner of a file.
    - Before, you would use `./pants list foo.py`. Now this gives you back the file name `foo.py`.
    - It's not clear what metadata is being applied for a file, and where to go to edit that metadata.
5. Substantially increases our code complexity and maintenance burden.
    - This is particularly tricky code to reason about, particularly because there are so many edge cases.
    - Example: this has interfered with adding `--query`, where it's unclear how we should handle generated subtargets.
    - Example: confusing how to integrate this with `dependees` https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/10354

items.title: No Pex overhead for changes to source files with `run` and `repl`
items.body:
Right now, we build a Pex with the source files. This shouldn't be necessary. We should run the sources as loose files, just like we do with Pytest where we simply populate the chroot with the files.

If done correctly, running `./pants run build-support/bin/check_banned_imports.py` would be nearly instantaneous. Changing its contents would not involve re-building a PEX.

We will still use a Pex for third party requirements.

items.title: Resolving requirements performance is still not acceptable
items.body:
Resolving each distinct permutation of requirements is a frustrating user experience. While we've made optimizations to leverage Pex's cache, the performance is still very poor. For a user onboarding to Pants 2.0, they spent 4 minutes resolving requirements, and only 60 seconds running tests. Those requirements were identical except for one having 48 reqs and the other 49 reqs.

We may want to consider an option to allow users to have less correctness for the sake of better performance. For example, build a single big venv and depend on it, so that we only need to resolve requirements once like a normal Python repo would do.

John has also pointed out in the past that us using loose interpreter constraints, such as `>=Py37`, means that each Pex does far more work than we'd like. We still want to pass the full constraints to Pex, but possibly, Pex should have an option to say "use the first interpreter that matches, don't build for every version"? When using `./pants binary`, it's important that the outputted Pex is built for all possible interpreter versions; but when doing things like `test` and `run`, we only need a single interpreter.

items.title: Allow ignoring the cache for Pytest
items.body:
Several users have expressed that it is challenging to test the behavior of Pants because it caches every test result, and there is no easy way in Pants 2.0 to ignore the cache without re-resolving all the requirements.

`--debug` doesn't work well because that only runs one single target. Adding whitespace to files is a workaround, but clunky and we need to do better than that.

Instead, we want some new options like `--pytest-cache-ignore` or `--test-ignore` that will rerun the tests, but without re-resolving requirements. Possibly, there would also be a way to re-resolve requirements.

Closely relates to https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/10156, but it may be possible to solve this without that.

items.title: Teach `dependees` how to work with generated subtargets
items.body:
Right now, `./pants dependees` will always return original addresses, rather than generated subtargets:

```
▶ ./pants dependees src/python/pants/util
build-support/migration-support:tests
pants-plugins/src/python/internal_backend/utilities:utilities
src/python/pants/auth:auth
src/python/pants/backend/native/config:config
src/python/pants/backend/native/subsystems:subsystems
src/python/pants/backend/native/subsystems/utils:utils
src/python/pants/backend/pants_info:pants_info
src/python/pants/backend/project_info:project_info
src/python/pants/backend/python:python
src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference:dependency_inference
src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference:tests
src/python/pants/backend/python/lint/bandit:bandit
src/python/pants/backend/python/lint/black:black
src/python/pants/backend/python/lint/docformatter:docformatter
src/python/pants/backend/python/lint/flake8:flake8
src/python/pants/backend/python/lint/isort:isort
src/python/pants/backend/python/lint/pylint:pylint
src/python/pants/backend/python/rules:integration
src/python/pants/backend/python/rules:rules
src/python/pants/backend/python/rules:tests
src/python/pants/backend/python/subsystems:subsystems
src/python/pants/backend/python/typecheck/mypy:mypy
```

In contrast, `dependencies` understands generated subtargets:
```
▶ ./pants dependencies src/python/pants/backend/python/lint/isort:integration
src/python/pants/backend/python/lint/isort/rules.py
src/python/pants/backend/python/target_types.py
src/python/pants/base/specs.py
src/python/pants/core/goals/fmt.py
src/python/pants/core/goals/lint.py
src/python/pants/core/util_rules/determine_source_files.py
src/python/pants/engine/addresses.py
src/python/pants/engine/fs.py
src/python/pants/engine/rules.py
src/python/pants/engine/selectors.py
src/python/pants/engine/target.py
src/python/pants/testutil/external_tool_test_base.py
src/python/pants/testutil/option/util.py
```

It would be helpful if `dependees` also understood generated subtargets. The output would be more consistent with the rest of Pants and it would result in finer grained caching when using `--changed-dependees`.

The tricky part is that the goal must continue to understand traditional targets that are not generated.

items.title: Error for unrecognized symbols in BUILD files is not the one we expect
items.body:
Current:

```
pants.base.exceptions.MappingError: Failed to parse src/python/pants/util/BUILD:
NameError("name 'python_tests2' is not defined",)
```

Expected:
```
Target type 'python_tests'2 is not registered.

All valid target types: ['python_binary', ...]
```

The error message is being applied too late.

items.title: Include package in workunit `name`s
items.body: `name` has the disadvantage currently of being too short to differentiate a workunit in one package from another in a different package. Although we continue to think that function names will _not_ be a public API (ie, not guaranteed to be stable between releases), it probably makes sense for the names to be long enough to avoid trivial collisions between packages.

items.title: Pants hangs in materialize_directories (again)

labels.name: ui
labels.description: The dynamic UI and CLI workunit logging

items.body: This bisected to #10234 At that commit this consistently hangs for me after having output the setup.py chroot to disk in `dist/`: ``` $ ./pants setup-py src/python/pants/testutil:testutil_wheel 04:17:57 [INFO] initializing pantsd... 04:17:57 [INFO] pantsd initialized. items.title: awslambda's configuration of the Pex resolve to target linux is flawed

labels.name: rules
labels.description: Issues pertaining to v2 rules shipped with Pants.

items.body:
It looks like there are two bugs here:
https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/39ae9b9a8be2f14343dde4198043c339148d58f4/src/python/pants/backend/awslambda/python/awslambda_python_rules.py#L62-L79

1. When using --platform with Pex, Pex does not check to see if the given platform is available locally via a discoverable interpreter that matches and instead assumes the platform is foreign, requiring pre-built wheels to be present.
2. The platform used is limited to manylinux ruling out use of non-manylinux wheels. Since the target OSes are ~known (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/lambda-python.html) its definitely possible to have non-manylinux wheels pre-built that work on the target AMIs.

To fix 1 we could try to detect the current platform if running locally and otherwise looks at the target platform we're requesting in remote execution. There is currently no reasonable way to do this that I'm aware of. Alternatively, Pex would need a feature that allows scanning all discoverable interpreters to find a local one matching --platform, and if found, loosen the `--no-build` constraint implicitly applied to `--platform` resolves.

To fix 2 just requires `s/manylinux2014/linux/` and possibly redundantly setting the already default `--manylinux=manylinux2014` Pex option for documentation purposes / emphasis.

items.title: LD_LIBRARY_PATH for pytest
items.body:
How to set `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` when running `pants test` ?

I am trying to write a test that depends on tesserocr, the python wrapper for tesseract. Tesseract requires `libtesseract.so.4` to be available through `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`. Since this environment variable needs to be set before the python process starts so that the linker can find the library, I cannot just add `os.environ['LD_LIBRARY_PATH'] = ...` in the python code.

I tried to run `export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lib` before running `pants test`, that did not work.
I could not find in the options of pants a way to set this environment variable in the process spawned by pytest.

There was an issue opened for this for [java](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/2382) but I could not find a way to do it with python.

items.title: Workunit completion not logged on master
items.body: Previously, when `--no-dynamic-ui`, workunits would log completion as well as starting. But in the last week, workunit completion is not rendering when `--no-dynamic-ui`. In particular, this means that we don't log completing or failing tests in CI.

items.title: remoting: cleanup process execution options
items.body: Similar to what was done in https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/pull/10215 to refactor remote execution options into a single struct, we should also wrap the process execution strategy options into a single struct to simplify `Core::new` (e.g., `process_execution_local_parallelism` and the other similarly named `process_execution` arguments).

items.title: pantsd leaks memory on ubuntu linux box
items.body: We have an EC2 machine running ubuntu `Linux ip-10-1-201-194 5.3.0-1028-aws #30~18.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Mon Jun 22 15:48:21 UTC 2020 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux` Pantsd leaks memory which causes the machine to hang a few times a week. @stuhood FYI

items.title: Allow a strong-weak cycle to be entered from either end
items.body:
For example, for the following cyclic graph:
```
digraph {
  A -> B [label=strong];
  B -> A [label=weak, style=dashed];
}
```
... there are two potential entrypoints. The current behavior is that:
*  If a caller requests `A` first:
    1. `A` will start and request `B` with a strong edge, which will succeed.
    2. `B` will start and request `A` with a weak edge, which will detect a cycle and
       return None.
    3. `B` will complete as Dirty.
    4. `A` will complete as Clean.
* If a caller requests `B` first:
    1. `B` will run and request `A` with a weak edge, which will succeed.
    2. `A` will run and request `B` with a strong edge, which will cycle detect and see a cycle
       of running nodes  which would cause it to deadlock if it requested `B`. It will fail with a cycle
       error, because it is not able to "cancel" or restart the computation of `B` (which would allow
      `B` to instead observe `None` rather than continuing to wait on `A`).

----

It should be possible to make this case consistent when `B` is requested first by allowing `B` to run multiple times (ie, until it reaches a consumer-specific fixpoint).

items.body:
A rule-based implementation would have to request `_Options`, which is a private type we may not want to expose.

items.title: Remove recursive options
items.body:
`recursive=True` options are problematic because nothing enforces that sub-scopes consume them, and in the context of v2, the "sub scope" relationship between a v1 `Goal` and v1 `Task` is no longer a thing. Scoped `Subsystem`s might become a thing (see #10156 for example), but the recursive relationship is safer there, because the creation of a scoped instance of a `Subsystem` is an explicit opt-in.

The global recursive options are:

```
src/python/pants/option/global_options.py
169-            "-l",
170-            "--level",
173:            recursive=True,
--
860-            "--colors",
863:            recursive=True,
--
924-            "-q",
925-            "--quiet",
927:            recursive=True,
--
942-            "--fail-fast",
945:            recursive=True,
--
951-            "--cache-key-gen-version",
954:            recursive=True,
--
968-            "--max-subprocess-args",
972:            recursive=True,
```

Some of these should just be immediately removed pre-2.0... others need replacement.

----

In particular, `quiet`/`color`/`level` need a v2 replacement. logging implementations generally use language-level modules/packages to select code, but it's possible that our `workunit` and/or `RuleGraph` frameworks allow for something that would be a better fit for how logic is organized.

items.title: Injecting Union[AddressSpecs, FilesystemSpecs] allows for divergence in goal implementations
items.body:
The specs that we inject for a `@goal_rule` are `Union[AddressSpecs, FilesystemSpecs]`, which means that there are technically two entrypoints to the graph, containing different rules and having different dependencies.

This could potentially allow for divergence of implementation, where (for example) the `test` goal uses completely different rules to run.

items.title: pantsd init logs printed out in UTC
items.body:
The Pants client prints out the pantd init messages in UTC while regular log messages are printed in the local time zone. The same time zone should be used for both types of messages for consistency.

Redacted logs:

```
$ ./pants test XXX
20:04:44 [INFO] initializing pantsd...
20:04:46 [INFO] pantsd initialized.
13:06:26.60 [INFO] Completed: Building requirements.pex with 30 requirements: XXX (501 characters truncated)
13:06:32.18 [INFO] Completed: Run Pytest for XXX
13:06:32.18 [INFO] Tests succeeded: XXX
```

items.title: Retry for filesystem changes should either use both time and attempts, or be infinite
items.body:
In #9920 I changed `Graph::get` to backoff for a time period in order to account for "many small invalidations occurring rapidly", as is the case with `fmt`. But there is another case that using time alone does not account for, and that's long running tests: our 60 second timeout is significantly shorter than some integration tests, which means that a file change invalidating a test that runs for longer than 60 seconds will immediately fail with:
```
Exception: Exhausted retries while waiting for the filesystem to stabilize.
```

We should either use both time _and_ an attempt count, or consider removing the timeout here entirely and just retrying indefinitely while files are changing.

items.title: [v2 pytest coverage] Missing coverage data.
items.body:
Coverage data/report only reports on source files that are directly under the target being tested.

For example,
 I have `python_tests(name=tests-x)` which tests `python_library(name=x)` 
`python_library(name=x)`  has `python_library(name=A)` and  `python_library(name=B)` as dependencies (specified in build files)
when running tests on `tests-x` the coverage data doesn't include source files from python libraries A & B.

The interpreter constraint of `CPython>=2.7,<3,==3.6.*` is completely invalid since `,` is an AND operator. That will always select 0 interpreters since you can't be both `<3` and exactly `3.6.*`.

items.title: Polish and document v2 Pytest coverage
items.body:
* [x] Redesign how Pants calculates what files to report on. #10027 and https://docs.google.com/document/d/13KbevWxXZsYUeJ6OUiz0nl2csYXCKFCe24eK91NPw6k/edit#.
* [x] Allow multiple formats in a single run.
* [x] Allow using a config file.
* [x] Document on the new site. https://pants.readme.io/v2.0/docs/python-test-goal#coverage

Not in scope:
* Get it working with Python 2.
* Report on files never touched by Pants. This is how Coverage works without Pants too.

items.title: Tolerate build graph cycles
items.body: Unfortunately these exist in the real world, and we should still work with them when possible. For example, unless some goal has to operate recursively (e.g., JVM compile), it can usually work with cycles.

items.title: Auto-generate options reference
UI polish
items.body:
The dynamic UI needs to be stable and provide an impressive user experience. 

Sub-issues:

- [x] allowing for streaming, expressive failure for workunits to fix https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/54ff280ce711e0befb9c585098b4cf5c4849106f/src/python/pants/core/goals/test.py#L35-L37
- [x] dynamic-ui doesn't scroll properly when it is done running #10005 
- [ ] resizing terminal/panel causes UI to glitch #9962
- [x] tty-detection on stderr does not work in travis or circle #9924

items.title: pantsd on by default
items.body: pantsd should be stable enough that we can enable it by default, and rely on it for performance gains.

items.title: Implicit targets and file-level deps
items.body:
We want to minimize the amount of BUILD file boilerplate that is necessary to adopt Pants. In cases where we can figure out what the right thing to do is, we should do that even without corresponding BUILD file structures.

A big part of this involves inferring dependencies where possible, e.g., by analyzing import statements in .py files. 
These inferred dependencies naturally exist at the file level (that is, they express a dependency of a single file on another single file). So it makes sense to be able to model dependencies at that level, instead of/as well as at the target level. 

Having file-level deps allows us to have "implicit targets" at the file level. So, for example, if the user enters `./pants binary path/to/main.py` we can act as-if there's a corresponding python_binary target, even if there isn't one.

items.title: include a script that runs the command line whenever `--no-process-execution-cleanup-local-dirs` is specified
items.body:
Today I was trying to debug an issue with a user on `#getting-started` in the pantsbuild slack, and asked them to use `--no-process-execution-cleanup-local-dirs`. It turns out that even with `-ldebug`, process executions are no longer printed anywhere, so it's impossible to recover the command line arguments and environment variables that a command ran with. This makes it difficult to use the preserved chroot to debug things.

If we also wrote an executable script `run.sh` that contains the appropriate environment variables and command line arguments present in the `Process` invocation, we could more easily use `--no-process-execution-cleanup-local-dirs` to debug failing process executions.

items.title: Pants should handle more dynamic file structures for coverage
items.body:
Currently, pants requires test and source files to be co-located in order to be automatically picked up. It is possible that this will not be the case for all repositories. In order to produce coverage a different file structure, the **coverage** field would need to be added to each **python_tests()** target. 

Example file structure:
```
├── libraries
│   ├── utility_libraries
│   │   └── library_1
│   │       ├── BUILD
│   │       ├── library_1
│   │       │   ├── __init__.py
│   │       │   ├── source_file_1.py
│   │       │   ├── ....
│   │       │   └── source_file_n.py
│   │       └── tests_library_1
│   │            ├── __init__.py
│   │            ├── test_file_1.py
│   │            ├── ....
│   │            └── test_file_n.py
└── services
     └── utility_services
          └── service_1
               ├── BUILD
               ├── service_1
               │   ├── __init__.py
               │   ├── component_1
               │    │   ├── component_source_file_1
               │    │   ├── ....
               │    │   └── component_source_file_n.py
               │   ├── source_file_1.py
               │   ├── ....
               │   └── source_file_n.py
               └── tests_service_1
                    ├── __init__.py
                    ├── test_file_1.py
                    ├── ....
                    └── test_file_n.py
```
BUILD file:
```
python_library(
  name='service-lib',
  sources=['service_1/**/*.py'],
  dependencies=[]
)

python_tests(
  name="test",
  sources=['tests_service_1/*.py'],
  dependencies=[:service-lib],
  coverage=[service_1.source_file_1, 
            ..., 
            service_1.source_file_n, 
            service_1.component_1.component_source_file_1,
            ...,
            service_1.component_1.component_source_file_n]
)
```
While this works, it is rather verbose and prone to developers forgetting to add new modules to the coverage list. 

Pants should have an easier way to define situations like these.

Some possible ideas:
1. Support globbing in the coverage field
2. Read in sources from dependencies within the same BUILD file

items.title: dynamic-ui doesn't scroll properly when it is done running

labels.name: ui
labels.description: The dynamic UI and CLI workunit logging

items.body: this happens running in a terminal that is split horizontally, something like this: when pants finishes running, the scrolling is off, so I have to scroll up in order to see the results (of pytest in this case).

items.title: Cancel all work on the process execution CommandRunner when killed by a signal
items.body: When pants is killed with a signal, it currently does not kill child processes. We should add explicitly handling for this via signal handling that will attempt to kill all children spawned by the `CommandRunner` before terminating.

items.title: pantsd memory leak
release.sh allowed a release on a sha without wheels built yet
items.body:
I'm about 95% sure that `release.sh` on the `1.29.x` branch allowed me to run a release for `1.29.0rc2` when the wheels weren't available yet.

I did not notice until afterwards that the wheels shards had not completed for the SHA (they still haven't as of now: https://travis-ci.com/github/pantsbuild/pants/builds/169970843), so I'm curious which wheels we ended up downloading.

items.title: remove cargo-fetcher fork

labels.name: rust-backend
labels.description: Tickets to do with pants's support of the rust programming language.

items.body:
In #9973 we temporarily create a fork of the `cargo-fetcher` crate which makes the `Krate` struct derive from `serde::Serialize` and `serde::Deserialize`. This is necessary to make the resolve cacheable.

The current iteration of #9973 would be difficult to push to the upstream `cargo-fetcher` project, since it requires interacting with the pants LMDB store to work. The `brfs` crate in this repo would be one way to allow pants to consume a more general `cargo-fetcher` binary that just writes to the filesystem instead of the pants LMDB store.

items.title: [python] Add support for raw coverage reports
items.body:
[Coverall](https://coveralls.io/) (a service similar to codecov.io) has a [python plugin](https://github.com/z4r/python-coveralls) that wants the ["raw" coverage data file](https://github.com/z4r/python-coveralls#coveralls-options). not the XML report generated from it.


I though about adding support to that by changing [ReportType](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/97e6ba3e6a32b9ab70a18da27e4893ce12515063/src/python/pants/backend/python/rules/pytest_coverage.py#L200) to be a flag based enum.
i.e. do something like

```python
class ReportType(Flags):
    CONSOLE = ("console", "report")
    XML = ("xml", None)
    HTML = ("html", None)
    RAW= ("raw", None)
```

and then change the processing code to handle and multiple values in this enable and output all the requested report types.
How would I go about specifying an option of a flag enum type?
can I just pass a class method as a type to the register() method that will get a list (from toml) and will return the enum type ?
i.e. something like:
```python
register("--report", type=ReportType.from_list_or_str)
```
my guess is that wouldn't work because pants looks at the type and checks if this is an enum to list possible values, so do we need to first add support for flags enums in the options parsing part of pants ?

@stuhood @Eric-Arellano

items.title: build-checker step fails: site-packages as dist.location is ambiguous
items.body:
I [posted this on slack](https://pantsbuild.slack.com/archives/C046T6T9U/p1591135762279600), but have since gathered more detail so I figured I would post here.

I'm trying to upgrade to pants version 1.26, from 1.22. 

When running any lint task, I get this error:

```
/Users/remi/.cache/pants/setup/bootstrap-Darwin-x86_64/1.26.0_py37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pex/pex_builder.py", line 300, in add_distribution
    dist_name = dist_name or os.path.basename(dist.location)
Exception message: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'location'
```
(full stacktrace at the bottom of this issue)

I used pdb to take a look, and it seems the problem is in this snippet:

https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/release_1.26.0/contrib/python/src/python/pants/contrib/python/checks/tasks/checkstyle/checkstyle.py#L188-L195

For me, the working set resolves `pantsbuild.pants.contrib.python.checks.checker==1.26` to the following dists:
```
pantsbuild.pants.contrib.python.checks.checker 1.26.0 (/Users/remi/.cache/pants/plugins/pantsbuild.pants.contrib.python.checks.checker-1.26.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl-install)
six 1.15.0 (/Users/remi/.cache/pants/setup/bootstrap-Darwin-x86_64/pants.jdiS1p/install/lib/python3.7/site-packages)
pyflakes 2.1.1 (/Users/remi/.cache/pants/plugins/pyflakes-2.1.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl-install)
pycodestyle 2.4.0 (/Users/remi/.cache/pants/plugins/pycodestyle-2.4.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl-install)
```
The problem lies with `six`, whose `dist.location` is `~/.cache/pants/setup/bootstrap-Darwin-x86_64/pants.jdiS1p/install/lib/python3.7/site-packages`. When that location is passed to `pex_builder.add_dist_location`, pex_builder cannot work out what distribution actually needs to be added.

I assume the reason `six` is in site-packages is that it's also a transitive dependency of pants code (not just checker code). `six` is also in the `~/.cache/pants/plugins`  directory as a .whl-install in my sys.path, but I guess it's not chosen as the dist.location, probably because it's later in the list.

However, I'm not sure why I'm hitting this but presumably other Pants users haven't had this issue. Maybe something is different about my environment? Or maybe my interpretation of the problem is wrong?

By the way, I'm reproducing the problem on both linux and mac, with `~/.cache`, `.pants.d`, and `.local_artifact_cache` cleaned. Any "quick fix" would be super helpful.




Here is the full stack-trace:
```
➜  base git:(remi-upgrade-pants-1.26) $ ./pants lint company/project/database/:db_connector_test
/Users/remi/.cache/pants/setup/bootstrap-Darwin-x86_64/1.26.0_py37/bin/pants:8: DeprecationWarning: DEPRECATED: option 'glob_expansion_failure' in global scope will be removed in version 1.27.0.dev0.
  If you currently set `--glob-expansion-failure=error`, instead set `--files-not-found-behavior=error`.
  sys.exit(main())
/Users/remi/.cache/pants/setup/bootstrap-Darwin-x86_64/1.26.0_py37/bin/pants:8: DeprecationWarning: DEPRECATED: option 'glob_expansion_failure' in global scope will be removed in version 1.27.0.dev0.
  If you currently set `--glob-expansion-failure=error`, instead set `--files-not-found-behavior=error`.
  sys.exit(main())
/Users/remi/.cache/pants/plugins/astroid-1.6.6-py2.py3-none-any.whl-install/astroid/interpreter/_import/spec.py:6: DeprecationWarning: the imp module is deprecated in favour of importlib; see the module's documentation for alternative uses
  import imp
/Users/remi/.cache/pants/setup/bootstrap-Darwin-x86_64/1.26.0_py37/bin/pants:8: DeprecationWarning: DEPRECATED: option 'glob_expansion_failure' in global scope will be removed in version 1.27.0.dev0.
```

items.title: Garbage collection of the store is overly eager
items.body:
I've seen a few cases of errors like:
```
File with digest Digest(Fingerprint<..>, 5175) not found
```
and
```
Couldn't find file contents for "contrib/go/src/python/pants/contrib/go/tasks/BUILD"
```
...which occur during 100% local runs with pantsd.

This is not confirmed, but I have a strong suspicion that when `pantsd` is running in multiple repositories (note: different repositories, although that doesn't feel strictly necessary), that garbage collection is overly eager. I suspect that multiple repositories is the relevant bit, because this garbage collection was deployed at scale in a single repository at Twitter, and we had no reports of this kind of issue.

----

Regardless, this probably boils down to leases not being extended on things that are being held in memory by `pantsd`, which then allows other `pantsd` to clear them.

To work around the issue, in some cases the `pantsd` process can be killed/restarted. In other cases, when content contained within a "directory" has been garbage collected, it's necessary to remove `~/.cache/pants/lmdb_store`.

items.title: tty-detection on stderr does not work in travis or circle

labels.name: ui
labels.description: The dynamic UI and CLI workunit logging

items.body: Using `isatty` on `stdout` seems to work fine in Travis and Circle CI (as evidenced by #9801), but for some reason we do not detect that `stderr` `isatty` in those environments (NB: I haven't actually confirmed this, but we're not explicitly setting the setting to true anywhere), and have thus needed to turn it off manually.

items.title: Deprecate the indexed Get form.

labels.name: rules
labels.description: Issues pertaining to v2 rules shipped with Pants.

labels.name: tech-debt
labels.description: Indicates technical debt flagged for clean up.

items.body: Right now we supprt indexing into the Get class as an alternative way to pass the product type parameter to a Get constructor. The syntax _looks_ like a Get type ascription, but its not that. Instead of trying to make this 1 bit of python look like typing might work in other languages, we should just use a constructor as we would for any other type.

items.title: Time display in log messages
items.body: We currently display the time in log messages as a UTC timestamp with several decimal places (e.g. `02:45:17:126 [INFO] Starting Create PEX`). I think we probably want this for some applications - pants output when running in a CI context, where the local time zone of the execution server is unknown or unimportant. But when running pants locally, it's unfriendly to have a UTC time zone. Do we want to add a global option to toggle between these formats? Should we be printing the time zone we use explicitly?

items.title: The PluginField extension mechanism fails for any universe with >1 Target subclass.

labels.name: rules
labels.description: Issues pertaining to v2 rules shipped with Pants.

items.body:
The fundamental issue is here:
https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/ef9e0543a80568ee270f63e1bbbeddb92c4faa08/src/python/pants/engine/target.py#L334-L339

The `cls.PluginField` will always be exactly `Target.PluginField` unless some subclass shadows the inner class member. I.E.:
```python
$ python
Python 3.8.3 (default, May 17 2020, 18:15:42) 
[GCC 10.1.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> class Outer:
...   class Inner:
...     ...
... 
>>> class SubclassNaive(Outer):
...   ...
... 
>>> class SubclassVerbose(Outer):
...   class Inner:
...     ...
... 
>>> Outer.Inner is SubclassNaive.Inner
True
>>> Outer.Inner is SubclassVerbose.Inner
False
>>> 
```

The effect of which is probably best shown with a few tests:
```diff
$ git diff src/python/pants/engine/target_test.py
diff --git a/src/python/pants/engine/target_test.py b/src/python/pants/engine/target_test.py
index f2646d33c..16a3a9060 100644
--- a/src/python/pants/engine/target_test.py
+++ b/src/python/pants/engine/target_test.py

+from pants.engine.rules import RootRule, RuleIndex, rule
 from pants.engine.selectors import Get, Params
 from pants.engine.target import (
     AmbiguousCodegenImplementationsException,
@@ -270,35 +270,75 @@ def test_async_field() -> None:
     assert "//:lib" in str(exc)
 
 
-def test_add_custom_fields() -> None:
-    class CustomField(BoolField):
-        alias: ClassVar = "custom_field"
-        default: ClassVar = False
+class RustTarget(Target):

+    core_fields: ClassVar = (Dependencies, Sources)
+
+
+class RustEditionCustomField(StringField):

+
+
+class FortranCustomField(BoolField):
+    alias: ClassVar = "custom_field"
+    default: ClassVar = False
 
-    union_membership = UnionMembership({FortranTarget.PluginField: [CustomField]})
-    tgt_values = {CustomField.alias: True}
+
+def assert_fortran_target_fields(union_membership: UnionMembership) -> None:
+    assert {FortranExtensions, FortranSources, FortranCustomField} == set(
+        FortranTarget.class_field_types(union_membership)
+    )
+
+
+def test_add_custom_fields_last_wins_bug() -> None:
+    union_membership = UnionMembership(
+        {
+            FortranTarget.PluginField: [FortranCustomField],
+            RustTarget.PluginField: [RustEditionCustomField],
+        }
+    )
+    assert_fortran_target_fields(union_membership)
+
+
+def test_add_custom_fields_full_union_bug() -> None:
+    rule_index = RuleIndex.create(
+        [
+            UnionRule(FortranTarget.PluginField, FortranCustomField),
+            UnionRule(RustTarget.PluginField, RustEditionCustomField),
+        ]
+    )
+    union_membership = UnionMembership(rule_index.normalized_rules().union_rules)
+    assert_fortran_target_fields(union_membership)
+
+
+def test_add_custom_fields() -> None:
+    union_membership = UnionMembership({FortranTarget.PluginField: [FortranCustomField]})
+    tgt_values = {FortranCustomField.alias: True}
     tgt = FortranTarget(
         tgt_values, address=Address.parse(":lib"), union_membership=union_membership
     )
 
-    assert tgt.field_types == (FortranExtensions, FortranSources, CustomField)
+    assert tgt.field_types == (FortranExtensions, FortranSources, FortranCustomField)
     assert tgt.core_fields == (FortranExtensions, FortranSources)
-    assert tgt.plugin_fields == (CustomField,)
-    assert tgt.has_field(CustomField) is True
+    assert tgt.plugin_fields == (FortranCustomField,)
+    assert tgt.has_field(FortranCustomField) is True
 
     assert FortranTarget.class_field_types(union_membership=union_membership) == (
         FortranExtensions,
         FortranSources,
-        CustomField,
+        FortranCustomField,
+    )
+    assert (
+        FortranTarget.class_has_field(FortranCustomField, union_membership=union_membership) is True
     )
-    assert FortranTarget.class_has_field(CustomField, union_membership=union_membership) is True
 
-    assert tgt[CustomField].value is True
+    assert tgt[FortranCustomField].value is True
 
     default_tgt = FortranTarget(
         {}, address=Address.parse(":default"), union_membership=union_membership
     )
-    assert default_tgt[CustomField].value is False
+    assert default_tgt[FortranCustomField].value is False
```

items.title: Dependency injection breaks resolution of transitive targets
items.body:
To reproduce, apply this diff to the example Python repo:

```diff
diff --git a/constraints.txt b/constraints.txt
index 443d4e7..4625cb3 100644
--- a/constraints.txt
+++ b/constraints.txt
@@ -31,4 +31,5 @@ tox==3.15.0
 translate==3.5.0
 urllib3==1.25.9
 virtualenv==20.0.20
-zipp==3.1.0
+zipp==1.2.0 ; python_version == '2.7'
+zipp==3.1.0 ; python_version > '2.7'
diff --git a/pants.ci.toml b/pants.ci.toml
index 9050246..4f8c79f 100644
--- a/pants.ci.toml
+++ b/pants.ci.toml
@@ -1,8 +1,7 @@
 # See https://pants.readme.io/docs/using-pants-in-ci.
 
 [GLOBAL]
-# Turn off the interactive UI.
-v2_ui = false
+dynamic_ui = false
 
 # Limit the maximum number of concurrent processes. Change this
 # to a number that makes sense for your CI setup, based on
diff --git a/pants.toml b/pants.toml
index 8a5fe1f..ece07e5 100644
--- a/pants.toml
+++ b/pants.toml
@@ -2,10 +2,11 @@
 # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (see LICENSE).
 
 [GLOBAL]
-pants_version = "1.28.0rc0"
+pants_version = "1.29.0.dev1"
 v1 =  false  # Turn off the v1 execution engine.
 v2 = true  # Enable the v2 execution engine.
-v2_ui = true  # Enable the v2 execution engine's terminal-based UI.
+dynamic_ui = true
+enable_pantsd = false  # Enable the Pants daemon for better performance.
 
 backend_packages = []  # Deregister all v1 backends.
 

```

Then, run `./pants test helloworld/util:tests`.

```
17:12:06:058 [INFO] Starting tests: helloworld/util:tests
17:12:06:059 [INFO] Starting tests: helloworld/greet:tests
17:12:06:068 [ERROR] 1 Exception encountered:

  Exception: Dep graph contained a cycle:
  Task(pants.engine.internals.graph:125:transitive_target(), (Addresses([Address(helloworld/greet, tests)]), helloworld/greet:tests), TransitiveTarget, true) <-
  Task(pants.engine.internals.graph:125:transitive_target(), (Addresses([Address(helloworld/greet, tests)]), helloworld/greet:tests), TransitiveTarget, true) <-
```

Using `./pants_from_sources`, we can see that the `await Get[Addresses](DependenciesRequest(Addresses))` in the transitive target rule is not working properly:

```diff
diff --git a/src/python/pants/engine/internals/graph.py b/src/python/pants/engine/internals/graph.py
index ce6839133..86f00889c 100644
--- a/src/python/pants/engine/internals/graph.py
+++ b/src/python/pants/engine/internals/graph.py
@@ -128,6 +128,7 @@ async def transitive_target(wrapped_root: WrappedTarget) -> TransitiveTarget:
     if not root.has_field(Dependencies):
         return TransitiveTarget(root, ())
     dependency_addresses = await Get[Addresses](DependenciesRequest(root[Dependencies]))
+    raise ValueError(dependency_addresses)
     dependencies = await MultiGet(Get[TransitiveTarget](Address, d) for d in dependency_addresses)
     return TransitiveTarget(root, dependencies)
 

```

This will end up being a reference to the target itself, rather than to its dependencies.

Further, the `resolve_dependencies` rule is never even used! Remove the previous diff, then apply this:

```diff
diff --git a/src/python/pants/engine/target.py b/src/python/pants/engine/target.py
index 25e561234..276078d08 100644
--- a/src/python/pants/engine/target.py
+++ b/src/python/pants/engine/target.py
@@ -1669,6 +1669,7 @@ class InferredDependencies(DeduplicatedCollection[Address]):
 async def resolve_dependencies(
     request: DependenciesRequest, union_membership: UnionMembership
 ) -> Addresses:
+    # raise ValueError()
     provided = request.field.sanitized_raw_value or ()
 
     # Inject any dependencies. This is determined by the `request.field` class. For example, if
```

But, if you unregister the dependency injection rules, this issue goes away:

```diff
diff --git a/src/python/pants/backend/codegen/protobuf/target_types.py b/src/python/pants/backend/codegen/protobuf/target_types.py
index 3878e8a1a..6eaa3ad0c 100644
--- a/src/python/pants/backend/codegen/protobuf/target_types.py
+++ b/src/python/pants/backend/codegen/protobuf/target_types.py
@@ -51,7 +51,7 @@ def inject_dependencies(_: InjectProtobufDependencies, protoc: Protoc) -> Inject
 
 def rules():
     return [
-        inject_dependencies,
-        UnionRule(InjectDependenciesRequest, InjectProtobufDependencies),
+        # inject_dependencies,
+        # UnionRule(InjectDependenciesRequest, InjectProtobufDependencies),
         SubsystemRule(Protoc),
     ]
```

Rule graphs
[bad_run.pdf](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/files/4690787/rule_graph.test.dot.pdf)
[good_run.pdf](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/files/4690790/rule_graph.test.dot.1.pdf)

items.title: Scrooge : compiler_option_sets doesn't work
items.body:
Hi

I'm trying to setup different Scala compiler args for scrooge-generated sources and everything else. 
Practically want to avoid failing on Scrooge generated source warnings

```
java_thrift_library(
    name='service',
    sources=['service.thrift'],
    compiler_option_sets = {"non_fatal_warnings"},
    strict_deps=True
)
```

But this doesn't get picked up and compiler uses default configuration

from pants.ini [compile.rsc]:
```
compiler_option_sets_enabled_args: {
  'fatal_warnings': [
    '-S-Xfatal-warnings',
    '-S-Ywarn-unused'
  ],
  'non_fatal_warnings': [
      '-S-nowarn'
  ]}

default_compiler_option_sets: ['fatal_warnings']
```

Maybe it has something to do with this line where only `strict_deps` is propogated?

https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/master/contrib/scrooge/src/python/pants/contrib/scrooge/tasks/scrooge_gen.py#L354

items.title: Slow export-dep-as-jar performance when exporting a large set of targets
items.body:
To reproduce, use Pants at commit 0f479f3e27e0d205b7b29edacaf7513ad4a4d84c 

```
./pants export-dep-as-jar <target_spec>...
```

where `<target_spec>...` contains a large number of targets where each target contains a large number of transitive dependencies. The Pants process has been running in the following step for 40 minutes
```
11:01:24 32:45   [export-dep-as-jar]
11:01:24 32:45     [export-dep-as-jar]
```

I used py-spy (https://github.com/benfred/py-spy) to produce the following CPU flamegraph
```
py-spy record -o profile.svg --pid <pid>
```

[profile.svg.zip](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/files/4662258/profile.svg.zip)
![Screenshot 2020-05-21 at 11 16 38](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1408093/82556127-aa036d00-9b58-11ea-9c05-4ef1711d182c.png)

This profile hints that the bottleneck lies in `Target.__eq__` comparisons in this line here
https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0f479f3e27e0d205b7b29edacaf7513ad4a4d84c/src/python/pants/backend/project_info/tasks/export_dep_as_jar.py#L566

Assuming that reference equality would work in this case, would it be possible to try and use some kind of identity set instead of `FrozenOrderedSet`? 🤔

items.title: Invalid project names of projects generated with `./pants idea-plugin`
items.body: Since the switch to `.idea` project type (https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/commit/bc8b6d2de121458aeab41c6b9afb45dea2b450f6), the name of IntelliJ project generated with `./pants idea-plugin` is the same as the folder name where the generated project files are located. Before the change, it was more descriptive, same as the imported target spec

items.title: Invalid abi tag in python_awslambda with python3.8
items.body:
In python3.8 `m` suffix on abi tags can be omitted, e.g. psycopg2 is published as `psycopg2_binary-2.8.5-cp38-cp38-manylinux1_x86_64.whl` (abi tag is `cp38`, for python 3.7 it was `cp37m`).

When python_awslambda builds a pex, it adds the `m` suffix to the abi tag in the target platform. See https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/9960d8834a369f6dea1a1b940eb039d90843db37/src/python/pants/backend/awslambda/python/awslambda_python_rules.py#L71 .

I think adding the suffix only up until runtime version 3.7 should fix this (similar as it is done for the `u` suffix in python 2.7).
Alternatively a way to override the behaviour would be needed.

items.title: Add support for local Pytest, Flake8, and Pylint plugins
items.body:
A user has a need for a local Pylint plugin. They cannot get it working with V2 currently because of the chroot model - the plugin files aren't showing up in their chroot. 

The plugins need to be configured globally in `pants.toml`, just like you can add published plugins via the `extra_requirements` options.

Two possible approaches to solving this:

1) Provide a generic mechanism to load any arbitrary target. Then, the user would create a `resources()` target, `python_library()` target, or even a custom `pylint_plugin()` etc, and in their config point to `build-support:pylint_plugin`.
    * Is this too generic? I don't see any downsides.
    * Benefit: can run Pants commands like `lint` on the plugin code itself.
2) In `pants.toml`, have the option simply be some globs to load, like the `sources` field.
    * This makes it harder to load multiple plugins.

Almost certainly the first approach is better.

items.title: Provide Accurate Feedback For Moving From the Depreciated `--source-source-roots` Option
items.body:
In version 1.28.0rc0, when one has the following configuration in `pants.toml`:

```
[source]
source_roots: """{
    "3rdparty/go": "(u'go_remote',)",
    "contrib/go/examples/3rdparty/go": "(u'go_remote',)",
    "app1": "(u'python',)",
    "app2": "(u'python',)",
    }"""
```

one gets the following message when one runs `./pants --no-verify-config help-advanced source`: 
```
  --source-source-roots=<map>
      default: { '3rdparty/go': (u'go_remote',), 'contrib/go/examples/3rdparty/go':
        (u'go_remote',), 'app': (u'python',), 'app2': (u'python',) }
      A map of source roots for source code to list of languages. Useful when you want
      to enumerate fixed source roots explicitly, instead of relying on patterns.
      DEPRECATED. will be removed in version: 1.30.0.dev0.
      Use --roots instead.
```

Changing, `source_roots` to `roots` produces an error (`[ERROR] Invalid option 'roots' under [source] in /git/repo/pants.toml`). Changing it to `root_patterns` does not produce an error, but it also does not show the correct default values when one run the `help-advanced` command written above.


## Story
As a pants user, I would like the CLI to correctly guide me from using the depreciated `--source-source-roots` option to using its replacement(s).

items.title: Harden PATH setting in pex runs
items.body:
The `interpreter_search_paths` can be used to adjust where `PEX` will go hunting for pythons.

But when trying to adjust the setting, it is not currently possible to "remove" the PATH from `interpreter_search_paths`. The following:
```
$ cat ~/.pants.rc
[python-setup]
# Avoid ever using a python that is not provided by pyenv.
interpreter_search_paths = ["<PYENV>"]
```
... fails under v2 because this line:
https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/e328b58af917440dc98c8aa88dbd49a9355c5e8d/src/python/pants/backend/python/rules/hermetic_pex.py#L53
...ends up relying on the presence of the default `PATH` entry from `interpreter_search_paths`... completely clearing the list results in not being able to find tools used by the shims (`bash`, `sed`, `cut`, etc), but also in not being able to find system headers.

The following _does_ work:
```
$ cat ~/.pants.rc
[python-setup]
interpreter_constraints = ["CPython>=3.7.7"]
```
... but is repository specific: i.e., it's not a good idea to install something like this globally, as it might override per-repo defaults.

----

In short: we need to decouple setting the PATH in executions from how `PEX` chooses interpreters.
